text: How long will ye imagine mischief against a man? ye shall be slain all of you: as a bowing wall shall ye be, and as a tottering fence.
text_kjv: How long will ye imagine mischief against a man? ye shall be slain all of you: as a bowing wall shall ye be, and as a tottering fence.
text_niv: How long will you assault a man?Would all of you throw him down—this leaning wall, this tottering fence?
text_esv: How long will all of you attack a man to batter him, like a leaning wall, a tottering fence?
text_nlt: So many enemies against one man —all of them trying to kill me.To them I’m just a broken-down wallor a tottering fence.
text_msg: How long will you gang up on me?How long will you run with the bullies?There's nothing to you, any of you—rotten floorboards, worm-eaten rafters,
text_nasb: How long will you assail a man, That you may murder [him], all of you, Like a leaning wall, like a tottering fence?
context: Psalm 62 is attributed to David, likely written during a period of intense personal threat and political instability, perhaps during Absalom's rebellion or another time when his enemies actively sought his downfall. The phrase 'imagine mischief' carries weight in ancient Near Eastern culture, where plots and conspiracies were common tools for usurping power or eliminating rivals. Accusations, both true and false, could be levied against a leader to undermine their authority and legitimacy. To ‘imagine mischief’ was more than idle speculation; it implied active plotting and planning to inflict harm. The metaphors 'bowing wall' and 'tottering fence' vividly illustrate the frailty and imminent collapse of his enemies’ schemes. These structures were common features of the ancient landscape, providing essential protection. A bowing wall indicated structural weakness and an inability to withstand pressure, while a tottering fence symbolized a barrier about to fall, offering no real defense. In David’s time, such images resonated deeply with the audience, painting a clear picture of the instability and ultimate failure of those who opposed him. Understanding the precariousness of political power and the constant threat of betrayal within the royal court provides a richer appreciation for the emotional and spiritual depth of David’s plea and declaration of faith in this Psalm.
meaning: Psalm 62:3 reveals David's righteous indignation and prophetic certainty. The question, 'How long will ye imagine mischief against a man?' expresses his frustration and weariness with the constant attacks and conspiracies against him. It’s not merely a complaint, but a challenge to the persistence and malice of his enemies. The declaration, 'ye shall be slain all of you,' is a bold statement of divine judgment. David isn't simply expressing a personal desire for revenge; he's asserting his belief that God will ultimately bring justice and defeat those who plot evil. This reflects a theology where God is the ultimate arbiter of justice, intervening in human affairs to protect the righteous and punish the wicked. The simile comparing his enemies to 'a bowing wall' and 'a tottering fence' illustrates their inherent weakness and impending doom. These structures, meant to provide stability and security, are on the verge of collapse, mirroring the fate of those who oppose God's anointed. Theologically, this verse reinforces the concept of divine sovereignty and the futility of opposing God's will. It speaks to the ultimate victory of righteousness over wickedness, and the inevitable downfall of those who seek to undermine God's chosen leaders. David's confidence stems not from his own strength, but from his unwavering trust in God's power and justice.
application: In modern application, Psalm 62:3 offers several key insights. First, it encourages us to recognize and confront the ‘mischief’ – the gossip, slander, and malicious intent – that exists in our own lives and communities. Whether in the workplace, social circles, or even within families, the verse calls us to be discerning and vigilant against those who seek to undermine others through harmful words and actions. Second, the verse reminds us that while we may face opposition and injustice, we should not resort to plotting or revenge ourselves. Instead, we should trust in God's ultimate justice, knowing that He will ultimately right the wrongs and protect the innocent. This doesn’t mean we should be passive; it calls us to act with integrity and righteousness, trusting God to handle the consequences. The metaphors of the 'bowing wall' and 'tottering fence' serve as a powerful reminder of the temporary and fragile nature of evil schemes. No matter how powerful or intimidating our enemies may seem, their plans are ultimately built on a weak foundation and are destined to crumble. Therefore, we should not be intimidated or discouraged by their threats. Instead, we should stand firm in our faith and continue to do what is right, knowing that God is on our side. Practically, this can mean speaking out against injustice, standing up for the vulnerable, and refusing to participate in gossip or slander. It means trusting in God's timing and plan, even when we don't see immediate results. It means focusing on building strong, lasting relationships based on honesty and respect, rather than engaging in petty rivalries or power struggles.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging the reality of evil and the presence of those who seek to harm others. Lord, give me discernment to recognize the 'mischief' around me and the courage to stand against it. I pray for those who are facing persecution and opposition. Strengthen them, protect them, and give them unwavering faith. Help me to trust in your justice, knowing that you will ultimately bring about what is right. May I not be swayed by fear or intimidation, but stand firm in my commitment to truth and righteousness. Let me be a force for good in this world, reflecting your love and compassion in all that I do. Thank you for being my refuge and my strength. Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'imagine mischief' goes beyond simple thoughts; it refers to actively planning and plotting to cause harm, inflict damage, or undermine someone's position, reputation, or well-being. It implies a deliberate intent to do evil.

faqs.answer: While the verse sounds like a curse, it's more accurately interpreted as a prophetic declaration. David expresses confidence in God's justice, not a desire for personal revenge. He trusts God to deal with his enemies.
